sources.title: Three Ages
sources.description: This gut busting comedy, starring Buster Keaton, charmingly explores love in the three ages of life - the prehistoric age, the roman age, and the modern age. Throughout the years, where love is concerned, does anything really change? You can read more about this film on its IMDb page . Enjoy!

sources.title: Three Ages (1923) HD with Score
sources.description: A parody of D.W. Griffith s Intolerance, dramatizing man s quest for love in three parallel settings a modern city, the Stone Age, and ancient Rome.

sources.description:
Three Ages (1923) is an American silent comedy film written, directed, and produced by Buster Keaton in collaboration with Edward F. Cline. Not only does this film mark Keatonâ€™s first feature-length directorial effort, but it also stands as a masterclass in comedic structure and cinematic parody. This restored and colorized edition revives one of Keatonâ€™s most important works, making it more accessible for modern audiences in the United States, Europe, and worldwide.

Plot Summary:
The film cleverly tells three parallel love stories set in different historical periods: the Stone Age, Ancient Rome, and the Modern Age (1920s America). In each story, Keaton plays a hopeful young man competing for the affection of a woman, only to find himself pitted against a stronger, wealthier rival.

Stone Age: Keaton is a bumbling caveman trying to win the heart of a cavewoman (Margaret Leahy) while competing with a brutish rival (Wallace Beery).

Ancient Rome: Keaton plays a Roman citizen in pursuit of the same woman, facing challenges from gladiatorial contests and public spectacle.

Modern Age: In a 1920s setting, Keaton plays a poor suitor vying for love in a world dominated by money, cars, and social status.

The three stories unfold simultaneously, intercut with one another, and each concludes with a resolution of the rivalry. True to Keatonâ€™s style, the film is filled with elaborate physical comedy, inventive stunts, and visual gags that highlight his genius for timing and subtle expression.

Three Ages is often described as Buster Keatonâ€™s parody of D.W. Griffithâ€™s Intolerance (1916), which similarly used multiple historical settings to tell interconnected stories. Unlike Griffithâ€™s heavy-handed moralizing, Keaton transforms the technique into a vehicle for comedy, satire, and romance.

This film is historically important as it launched Keaton into feature-length filmmaking after his successful run of short comedies. It also introduced audiences to his method of blending elaborate stunts with understated humor, a contrast to the broader slapstick of contemporaries like Harold Lloyd or Charlie Chaplin. Wallace Beeryâ€™s performance as the recurring rival adds depth and menace to Keatonâ€™s struggles, while Margaret Leahy provides the romantic center of each story.

As one of Keatonâ€™s earliest full-length works, Three Ages provides a fascinating look at both his comedic style and the evolution of silent-era storytelling. Its themes of rivalry, love, and perseverance remain timeless, making it a culturally and historically significant piece of cinema.
